messages.content:
I want to make LLM respond with in-text citations but unfortunately with the below prompt, LLM is sometimes providing in-text citations and sometimes its not. Please review my system prompt and let me know what needs to be changed.
### Prompt:
'''You are an Assistant tasked with providing answers to Lam Research employees question's using only the information found in a provided list of sources.
    You are not allowed to generate information from sources not included in the list. Be as descriptive as possible when answering user questions.
    If the information is insufficient, you should indicate that you don't know the answer and ask the user to rephrase the question and provide more context like the name of the system, or parts realated to the issue. You may ask clarifying questions to the user if needed. 
    The questions mostly relate to getting relevant information, plausible hypotheses,diagnosing wafer tools created by LAM Research, and test plans for typical problems faced by Lam Engineers. If the context mentions specific items such as parts, documents, quantity, etc, provide specific values pertaining to those in your response.
    Remember to include in-text citations as numbers in square brackets, such as [2]. List your sources separately, like [1][2]. 
    In scenarios where the user asks a specific detail with respect to a particular part/document/file. Use only the context from that filename as much as possible to generate an answer and DO NOT MENTION THE OTHER SOURCES AS CITATIONS OR USE THEM TO FRAME THE ANSWER.
    If the provided context does not allow for an answer to be generated, DO NOT include any citations in the response. 
    DO NOT MENTION SOURCES AS SEPARATE SECTION THE RESPONSE; JUST IN-TEXT CITATIONS IN THE RESPONSE AS SHOWN ABOVE AND AS PROVIDED IN THE EXAMPLES.
    Here's an example of an employee question, and a sample response.

    #### START EXAMPLE

    ------ Example Input ------
    Sources:
    [1] (b) All steel shall be killed or semi-killed(c) All material precursors shall be virgin material produced by extraction or vacuum distillation processes(4) Workmanship, Finish, and Appearance: for technical reasons or for reasons of Lam-Customer acceptance, it may be necessary to clarify or specify requirements related to material workmanship, finish, or appearance. Authors of Lam materials specifications are reminded that our customers may not accept parts that differ significantly in color, texture, inclusions, anodization color, or other differences. Typical requirements in this section might include:(a) Material shall be free from voids, cracks, seams or other material defects which could affect the performance of the finished part(b) Material shall be uniform in color (c) Inclusions shall be less than 1 mm in any dimension and shall not occur more than 1 in any 100 cm3 volume.Performance Requirements: though rarely prescribed, it may be necessary to impose requirements on material in a way that simulates or presupposes environmental or use conditions in Lam products. Typical requirements in this section might include:(a)
    [2] Requirements that cannot be adequately specified by engineering documentation.See TABLE-3 for details. C4 Supplier Critical part with supplier lock but without POR control that has any of the following characteristics: ¬∑ Requires supplier expertise, fabrication methods, and/or materials that are unique and/or proprietary to a supplier to meet the part specifications. ¬∑ Requires co-development between Lam engineering and the supplier to meet fabricated part specifications.See TABLE-3 for details. C8 Supplier Critical part with POR control and LQD (Lam Quality Data) requirements.‚Ä¢ Proactive identification of part variability drivers to be used for analysis for Lam‚Äôs product and process development - Key dimensions, finishes, performance aspects, and features.See LQD-70995 (LQD-70995 LQD Approval, Structuring and Validation [LQD-41261] Engineering Procedure) and TABLE-3 for details. CAD Computer Aided Design CCP CCP ‚Äì Custom Commercial Part (Engineering Deliverable)See DDS-70269 (Lam Specification Sheets ‚Äì Source Controlled and Specification Controlled [DDS-5008] Engineering Procedure) for further details. 
    [3] Document Name:DDS-70184 PC Board Layout Deliverables [DDS-1017] Engineering Procedure Revision: 8.0Page 1 of 5 Functional Group: Engineering Leadership Team Process Owner: Perez, RaulTitle: Technical Program Manager 6 Authorized By: Bowser, DavidTitle: Mng Dir, Engineering Acknowledged By: Mueller, Gerhard [Sr. Mgr, Engineering]; Maruyama, Lourdes [Sr. Mgr, Engineering]; Langner, Peter [Director, Engineering]; McCool, Scott [Sr Manager- Engineering]; Lam, Connie [Mng Dir, Engineering]; Pham, Quang [Electrical Engineer 5]; Benavidez, Jr., Juan [Mng Dir, Engineering] DDS-70184 PC Board Layout Deliverables [DDS-1017] Engineering Procedure Rev: 8.0 Page 2 of 5PurposeThis procedure defines the following:‚Ä¢ Directories, zip file structure, and naming conventions‚Ä¢ PCB input design package ‚Äì the information and documentation required from the electrical design engineer to begin the printed circuit board (PCB) layout design (artwork)‚Ä¢ Artwork design standards ‚Äì this procedure defines the basic artwork design requirements, format, and nomenclatures the PCB designer uses when designing the PCB
    Question: What is the engineering specification for the dimensions of inclusions and quantity per volume?

    ------ Example Output ------
    Response when the answer is found: 
    The engineering specification for the dimensions of inclusions and quantity per volume is that inclusions should be less than 1 mm in any dimension and should not occur more than 1 in any 100 cm3 volume [1].

    Response when the answer is not found: 
    I'm sorry, I don't have enough information to answer this question. Try rephrasing the question and provide more details if possible.
	
	------ Example Input ------
    Sources:
    [1] Critical Part Classification Examples ‚Äì CV Part with Critical Features‚Äì 839-162726-002 ENG-73438 Critical and Commercial Part Definition and Classification Work Instruction Why is this part Engineering Critical? This part is used for accurate wafer placement. Variations in performance may result in customer escalations. Why is this part Supplier CV Critical? For DIA, if bearing fits improperly during assembly, it will have affect on bearing life. For parallelism, Robot would fail planarity test and would need to be re-built adding significant cost. For this reason, a critical features have been identified with 202-010823-002. With this part being classified as CV, SET will ensure inspections on this part are conducted according to the specification and any POR changes that impact that feature would require engineering approval. Why is this part NOT Safety Critical? Part failure would not expose personnel, facilities, or the community to hazards that could result in death, significant injury, or significant equipment damage. Why is this not C1? This assembly is 100% measurable with all features adequately specified by engineering documentation. Changes that don't impact the C1 processes are approved by SET. Y CV N Engineering Critical Supplier Critical Safety Critical
    [2] Critical Part Classification Examples ‚Äì CV Fabricated Part ‚Äì 853-A23506-008 ENG-73438 Critical and Commercial Part Definition and Classification Work Instruction Y CV N Engineering Critical Supplier Critical Safety Critical Why is this part Engineering Critical? This is a deposition gas box that controls the flow of process gases to the chamber and directly impacts on wafer performance. Failure of this part would result in a customer escalation Why is this part Supplier CV Critical? The part is 100% measurable and has critical assembly and test processes defined in a C1 specification. Why is this part NOT Safety Critical? Single-point part failure would not expose personnel, facilities, or the community to hazards that could result in death, significant injury, or significant equipment damage. Why is it not C1? All requirements, other than the C1 processes and controls (test specification), can be adequately specified by engineering documentation and are 100% measurable. Variation of fabrication methods, other than the C1 processes and controls, do not negatively impact part performance. Why is it not C4? Process change control is required for assembly and test of this part.
    [3] Critical Part Classification Examples ‚Äì CV Fabricated Part ‚Äì 715-800331-005 ENG-73438 Critical and Commercial Part Definition and Classification Work Instruction Why is this part Engineering Critical? This part is essentially a chamber wall; the foundation for the cantilever that the ESC/wafer sits on. Problems with this part will lead to escalations. Why is this part Supplier CV Critical? All requirements, other than the hard anodize, can be adequately specified by engineering documentation. Variation in the anodize method will have a negative impact on the part performance. Requires process and methods traceability. Why is this part NOT Safety Critical? title: üîì Whitelist third-party network

messages.content: I have an aws api gateway which has a a POST endpoint. I share this api with a third party. The api is currently in my org vpc and private, so the third party is unable to ping the api. I want to whitelist the network of the third party in my org aws account, so that I give them access to my api which will allow them to send requests securely

To whitelist a third party's network in your AWS account and allow them to access your private API Gateway endpoint, you can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Third Party's IP Range**: Obtain the IP address range (CIDR block) of the third party's network that you want to whitelist.

2. **Modify the Security Group**: Update the security group associated with your API Gateway's VPC endpoint to allow inbound traffic from the third party's IP range.

3. **Update the API Gateway Resource Policy**: Add a resource policy to your API Gateway to allow access from the third party's IP range.

Here is a step-by-step guide:

### Step 1: Identify the Third Party's IP Range
Ensure you have the correct CIDR block for the third party's network.

### Step 2: Modify the Security Group
1. Go to the AWS Management Console.
2. Navigate to the **VPC** service.
3. Select **Security Groups** from the left-hand menu.
4. Find the security group associated with your API Gateway's VPC endpoint.
5. Edit the inbound rules of the security group to allow traffic from the third party's IP range:
   - Type: HTTP (or HTTPS if your API uses HTTPS)
   - Protocol: TCP
   - Port Range: 80 (or 443 for HTTPS)
   - Source: The third party's CIDR block (e.g., `203.0.113.0/24`)

### Step 3: Update the API Gateway Resource Policy
1. Go to the AWS Management Console.
2. Navigate to the **API Gateway** service.
3. Select your API.
4. Go to the **Resource Policy** section.
5. Add a policy statement to allow access from the third party's IP range. Here is an example policy:

```json
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Principal": "*",
      "Action": "execute-api:Invoke",
      "Resource": "arn:aws:execute-api:region:account-id:api-id/stage-name/HTTP-VERB/resource-path",
      "Condition": {
        "IpAddress": {
          "aws:SourceIp": "203.0.113.0/24"
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

Replace the placeholders with your actual values:
- `region`: The AWS region where your API is deployed.
- `account-id`: Your AWS account ID.
- `api-id`: The ID of your API.
- `stage-name`: The stage name of your API (e.g., `prod`).
- `HTTP-VERB`: The HTTP method (e.g., `POST`).
- `resource-path`: The resource path of your API (e.g., `/myresource`).

### Step 4: Test the Configuration
Ask the third party to test accessing the API to ensure that the whitelisting is working correctly.

By following these steps, you should be able to securely whitelist the third party's network and allow them to send requests to your private API Gateway endpoint.

title: üìä Azure Activity logs

messages.content: What does Azure Activity logs track?

Azure Activity Logs provide a record of operations that were performed on resources in your Azure subscription. They help you understand the "what, who, and when" for any write operations (PUT, POST, DELETE) taken on the resources in your subscription. Here are some key aspects that Azure Activity Logs track:

1. **Administrative Operations**: These include operations such as creating, updating, or deleting resources.
2. **Service Health Events**: Information about the health of Azure services.
3. **Alert Events**: Alerts that are triggered based on specific conditions.
4. **Autoscale Events**: Information about autoscaling actions.
5. **Resource Health Events**: Information about the health of your resources.
6. **Policy Events**: Information about policy compliance.

These logs are essential for auditing, troubleshooting, and gaining insights into the operations performed within your Azure environment.
What logs do you get for free by virtue of using APIM?

When using Azure API Management (APIM), you get several types of logs for free that help you monitor and troubleshoot your APIs. These logs include:

1. **Activity Logs**: These logs provide a record of operations that were performed on the APIM service itself, such as creating or deleting an API, updating policies, etc. They help you understand the administrative actions taken on the APIM instance.

2. **Metrics**: Azure provides a set of metrics for APIM that you can use to monitor the performance and health of your APIs. These metrics include request count, response time, and other performance indicators.

3. **Diagnostic Logs**: APIM allows you to enable diagnostic logging for your APIs. This includes:
   - **Request Logs**: Logs of incoming requests to your APIs.
   - **Response Logs**: Logs of responses sent from your APIs.
   - **Backend Logs**: Logs of requests and responses between APIM and your backend services.

4. **Event Hub Logs**: You can configure APIM to send logs to Azure Event Hub for further processing and analysis.

5. **Azure Monitor Logs**: You can integrate APIM with Azure Monitor to collect and analyze logs and metrics. This includes setting up alerts based on specific conditions.

6. **Application Insights**: You can integrate APIM with Azure Application Insights to get detailed telemetry data, including request and response logs, performance metrics, and more.

While some of these logs and metrics are available for free, others may incur additional costs depending on the volume of data and the specific Azure services you use for log storage and analysis.
Are APIM Activity logs part of Azure Activity Log?

Yes, APIM (Azure API Management) Activity Logs are part of the Azure Activity Log. The Azure Activity Log provides a record of operations that were performed on resources in your Azure subscription, including those related to APIM. These logs capture administrative operations such as creating, updating, or deleting APIs, configuring policies, and other management actions performed on the APIM service.

By being part of the Azure Activity Log, APIM Activity Logs help you understand the "what, who, and when" for any write operations taken on your APIM resources. This is useful for auditing, troubleshooting, and gaining insights into the administrative actions performed within your APIM instance.

title: üíª AKS cluster OS

messages.content: Does an AKS cluster have an OS? If so how is its version maintained?

Yes, an Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) cluster does have an operating system. The nodes in an AKS cluster run on virtual machines (VMs) that have an underlying operating system. Typically, these VMs run a Linux distribution, such as Ubuntu, or a Windows Server version, depending on the configuration of the cluster.

### Maintaining the OS Version

1. **Node Image Upgrades**: AKS provides node image upgrades to ensure that the nodes are running the latest OS version with the latest security patches and updates. These upgrades can be performed manually or automatically.

2. **Cluster Upgrades**: When you upgrade the Kubernetes version of your AKS cluster, the node images are also updated to the latest supported OS version for that Kubernetes version.

3. **Automatic OS Patching**: AKS can be configured to automatically apply OS patches to the nodes. This helps in keeping the nodes secure and up-to-date without manual intervention.

4. **Custom Node Images**: If you have specific requirements, you can create custom node images with your desired OS version and configurations, and use these images for your AKS nodes.

### Steps to Maintain OS Version

1. **Check Current Node Image Version**:
   - You can check the current node image version using the Azure CLI or the Azure portal.

2. **Upgrade Node Image**:
   - Use the Azure CLI command `az aks nodepool upgrade` to upgrade the node image.
   - Example:
     ```sh
     az aks nodepool upgrade --resource-group myResourceGroup --cluster-name myAKSCluster --nodepool-name myNodePool --node-image-only
     ```

3. **Enable Automatic OS Patching**:
   - You can enable automatic OS patching when creating a node pool or update an existing node pool to enable this feature.
   - Example:
     ```sh
     az aks nodepool update --resource-group myResourceGroup --cluster-name myAKSCluster --name myNodePool --enable-auto-upgrade
     ```

4. **Monitor and Manage**:
   - Regularly monitor the node status and ensure that the nodes are running the desired OS version.
   - Use Azure Monitor and other tools to keep track of the health and performance of the nodes.

By following these practices, you can ensure that the OS version of your AKS cluster nodes is maintained and kept up-to-date with the latest patches and updates.
Is AKS a PaaS MS service?

Yes, Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) is considered a Platform as a Service (PaaS) offering from Microsoft Azure. AKS provides a managed Kubernetes service that simplifies the deployment, management, and operations of Kubernetes clusters.

### Key Features of AKS as a PaaS:

1. **Managed Kubernetes**: AKS handles the complexities of Kubernetes management, including cluster upgrades, patching, and scaling, allowing you to focus on deploying and managing your applications.

2. **Integrated Services**: AKS integrates with other Azure services such as Azure Active Directory, Azure Monitor, and Azure DevOps, providing a seamless experience for managing and monitoring your applications.

3. **Automatic Scaling**: AKS supports both manual and automatic scaling of your Kubernetes clusters, enabling you to handle varying workloads efficiently.

4. **Security and Compliance**: AKS provides built-in security features, including network policies, Azure Policy integration, and role-based access control (RBAC), helping you meet your security and compliance requirements.

5. **Cost Management**: With AKS, you only pay for the virtual machines and associated storage and networking resources consumed by your Kubernetes nodes. The Kubernetes control plane is managed by Azure and is provided at no additional cost.

6. **Developer Productivity**: AKS simplifies the development and deployment process with tools like Azure Dev Spaces, Azure Pipelines, and Helm, enhancing developer productivity and accelerating time-to-market.

By leveraging AKS as a PaaS, organizations can benefit from the scalability, reliability, and security of Azure while reducing the operational overhead associated with managing Kubernetes clusters.
How does AKS manage vulnerabilities?

Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) employs several strategies and tools to manage and mitigate vulnerabilities, ensuring the security and integrity of your Kubernetes clusters. Here are the key aspects of how AKS manages vulnerabilities:

### 1. **Regular Patching and Updates**
- **Node Image Upgrades**: AKS provides regular updates to the node images, which include the latest security patches and updates for the underlying operating system. You can manually trigger these updates or configure automatic updates.
- **Kubernetes Version Upgrades**: AKS regularly releases new Kubernetes versions that include security patches and improvements. You can upgrade your cluster to the latest Kubernetes version to benefit from these updates.

### 2. **Security Features and Best Practices**
- **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: AKS integrates with Azure Active Directory (AAD) to provide fine-grained access control to cluster resources, ensuring that only authorized users can perform specific actions.
- **Network Policies**: AKS supports network policies to control the traffic flow between pods, enhancing the security of your applications by limiting communication to only what is necessary.
- **Azure Policy Integration**: AKS integrates with Azure Policy to enforce compliance and security policies across your clusters. You can use built-in policies or create custom policies to meet your specific requirements.

### 3. **Monitoring and Threat Detection**
- **Azure Security Center**: AKS integrates with Azure Security Center to provide advanced threat detection and security recommendations. Security Center continuously monitors your clusters for vulnerabilities and provides actionable insights to mitigate risks.
- **Azure Monitor**: Azure Monitor provides comprehensive monitoring and logging capabilities for your AKS clusters. You can set up alerts and dashboards to monitor the health and performance of your clusters and detect any anomalies.

### 4. **Container Image Security**
- **Azure Container Registry (ACR)**: ACR provides features like image scanning to detect vulnerabilities in container images. You can integrate ACR with security tools to automatically scan images for known vulnerabilities before deploying them to your AKS clusters.
- **Image Signing and Verification**: AKS supports image signing and verification to ensure that only trusted and verified images are deployed to your clusters.

### 5. **Isolation and Segmentation**
- **Node Pools**: AKS allows you to create multiple node pools with different configurations and security settings. You can isolate workloads with different security requirements by deploying them to separate node pools.
- **Pod Security Policies**: AKS supports pod security policies to enforce security standards for pod creation and operation, such as restricting the use of privileged containers or enforcing read-only root file systems.

### 6. **Regular Security Audits and Penetration Testing**
- **Security Audits**: Regular security audits and assessments are conducted to identify and address potential vulnerabilities in the AKS service.
- **Penetration Testing**: Microsoft conducts penetration testing on AKS to identify and mitigate security weaknesses.

By leveraging these strategies and tools, AKS helps you manage and mitigate vulnerabilities, ensuring the security and compliance of your Kubernetes clusters.

title: üìù Interview confidence example

messages.content: Fill in the blank: Do you have any examples from the interview that ____ confidence?
The sentence can be completed with the word "demonstrate" to make it: "Do you have any examples from the interview that demonstrate confidence?"
I was thinking of the word "bode". Is that relevant?

The word "bode" means to be an omen or a sign of a particular outcome. It is typically used in contexts where something is indicative of a future event, often with a positive or negative connotation. 

In the context of your sentence, "bode" would not be the most appropriate choice because it doesn't fit well with the idea of providing examples that show confidence. "Demonstrate" or "exhibit" would be more suitable words for that context. 

So, the sentence "Do you have any examples from the interview that bode confidence?" would not be correct. Instead, you could use:

"Do you have any examples from the interview that demonstrate confidence?"
I'm thinking of a word that means something like "instill in me a sense of"

Given that you are looking for a word that means "instill in me a sense of," the word "convey" would be a good fit. 

So, the sentence would be: "Do you have any examples from the interview that convey confidence?"
Am I thinking of "give me a vote of"?

The phrase "give me a vote of" is typically followed by words like "confidence" or "no confidence" and is used in contexts where someone is expressing their trust or lack thereof in someone else's abilities or decisions, often in formal settings like politics or business.

In the context of your sentence, it would not fit well. You are looking for a word that means "instill in me a sense of" confidence based on examples from an interview. 

The word "convey" or "demonstrate" would still be more appropriate. 

So, the sentence would be: "Do you have any examples from the interview that convey confidence?"
Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me ________ confidence?

The word you're looking for is likely "more" or "greater."

So, the sentence would be: "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me more confidence?" or "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me greater confidence?"
I'm looking for something like "a sense of" but it's a particular phrase I can't tihnk of. Give 10 examples

Sure, here are 10 phrases that might fit the context you're thinking of:

1. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a sense of confidence?"
2. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a feeling of confidence?"
3. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me an impression of confidence?"
4. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me assurance of confidence?"
5. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a boost of confidence?"
6. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a measure of confidence?"
7. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a degree of confidence?"
8. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a level of confidence?"
9. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a sense of security?"
10. "Do you have any examples from the interview that would give me a sense of trust?"

If none of these are the exact phrase you're thinking of, feel free to provide more context or details!

title: üìâ Time-series ML setups

messages.content: What ML loss functions and training setups are used for time-series forecasting with deep learning?

Time-series forecasting with deep learning involves predicting future values based on previously observed data. Various machine learning loss functions and training setups are used to optimize the performance of deep learning models for this task. Here are some common loss functions and training setups:

### Loss Functions

1. **Mean Squared Error (MSE)**
   - **Description**: Measures the average squared difference between the predicted and actual values.
   - **Formula**: \( \text{MSE} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2 \)

2. **Mean Absolute Error (MAE)**
   - **Description**: Measures the average absolute difference between the predicted and actual values.
   - **Formula**: \( \text{MAE} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} |y_i - \hat{y}_i| \)

3. **Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE)**
   - **Description**: Measures the average absolute percentage difference between the predicted and actual values.
   - **Formula**: \( \text{MAPE} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \left| \frac{y_i - \hat{y}_i}{y_i} \right| \times 100 \)

4. **Huber Loss**
   - **Description**: Combines the best properties of MSE and MAE, being less sensitive to outliers than MSE.
   - **Formula**: 
     \[
     L_\delta(y, \hat{y}) = \begin{cases} 
      \frac{1}{2}(y - \hat{y})^2 & \text{for } |y - \hat{y}| \leq \delta \\
      \delta |y - \hat{y}| - \frac{1}{2} \delta^2 & \text{otherwise}
     \end{cases}
     \]

5. **Quantile Loss**
   - **Description**: Used for predicting quantiles, useful for probabilistic forecasting.
   - **Formula**: 
     \[
     L_\alpha(y, \hat{y}) = \begin{cases} 
      \alpha (y - \hat{y}) & \text{for } y \geq \hat{y} \\
      (1 - \alpha) (\hat{y} - y) & \text{otherwise}
     \end{cases}
     \]

### Training Setups

1. **Sliding Window Approach**
   - **Description**: Uses a fixed-size window of past observations to predict the next value(s).
   - **Implementation**: Create overlapping windows of data and use them as input-output pairs for training.

2. **Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)**
   - **Description**: Models like LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) and GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit) are used to capture temporal dependencies.
   - **Implementation**: Use sequences of data as input to the RNN layers.

3. **Sequence-to-Sequence (Seq2Seq) Models**
   - **Description**: Consists of an encoder-decoder architecture, often used for multi-step forecasting.
   - **Implementation**: The encoder processes the input sequence, and the decoder generates the output sequence.

4. **Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)**
   - **Description**: Can be used to capture local patterns in time-series data.
   - **Implementation**: Apply 1D convolutions over the time-series data.

5. **Transformers**
   - **Description**: Attention-based models that can handle long-range dependencies.
   - **Implementation**: Use self-attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of different time steps.

6. **Hybrid Models**
   - **Description**: Combine different types of models, such as CNNs and RNNs, to leverage their strengths.
   - **Implementation**: Use CNN layers to extract features followed by RNN layers to capture temporal dependencies.

### Training Tips

- **Normalization**: Normalize the time-series data to improve model performance.
- **Regularization**: Use techniques like dropout to prevent overfitting.
- **Hyperparameter Tuning**: Experiment with different architectures, learning rates, and batch sizes.
- **Cross-Validation**: Use techniques like k-fold cross-validation to evaluate model performance.

By carefully selecting the appropriate loss function and training setup, you can build effective deep learning models for time-series forecasting.
Anything to explicitly capture the stochastic nature of time series?

Capturing the stochastic nature of time series is crucial for accurate forecasting, especially when dealing with uncertainty and variability in the data. Here are some approaches and models explicitly designed to handle the stochastic nature of time series:

### Probabilistic Forecasting Models

1. **Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs)**
   - **Description**: Incorporate uncertainty in the model parameters by treating them as distributions rather than fixed values.
   - **Implementation**: Use Bayesian inference methods like variational inference or Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) to estimate the posterior distributions of the parameters.

2. **Gaussian Processes (GPs)**
   - **Description**: Non-parametric models that provide a probabilistic approach to learning functions.
   - **Implementation**: Use GPs to model the time series, providing a distribution over possible functions that fit the data.

3. **DeepAR**
   - **Description**: A probabilistic forecasting model based on autoregressive recurrent networks.
   - **Implementation**: Train an RNN to output parameters of a probability distribution (e.g., Gaussian) for the next time step, conditioned on the past observations.

4. **Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCNs) with Probabilistic Outputs**
   - **Description**: Use TCNs to capture temporal dependencies and output probabilistic forecasts.
   - **Implementation**: Modify the output layer to predict parameters of a probability distribution (e.g., mean and variance for a Gaussian distribution).

### Stochastic Processes and Models

1. **Stochastic Differential Equations (SDEs)**
   - **Description**: Model the time series as a solution to a differential equation with a stochastic component.
   - **Implementation**: Use numerical methods to solve SDEs and fit them to the time series data.

2. **Hidden Markov Models (HMMs)**
   - **Description**: Model the time series as a sequence of observations generated by hidden states, each following a probability distribution.
   - **Implementation**: Use the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm to estimate the parameters of the HMM.

3. **State Space Models (SSMs)**
   - **Description**: Represent the time series as a combination of hidden states and observed variables, incorporating stochasticity in the state transitions and observations.
   - **Implementation**: Use Kalman filters for linear Gaussian SSMs or particle filters for non-linear/non-Gaussian SSMs.

### Hybrid and Ensemble Models

1. **Ensemble Methods**
   - **Description**: Combine multiple models to capture different aspects of the stochastic nature of the time series.
   - **Implementation**: Use techniques like bagging, boosting, or stacking to create an ensemble of models.

2. **Hybrid Models**
   - **Description**: Combine deterministic models (e.g., LSTMs, CNNs) with probabilistic components to capture both deterministic and stochastic aspects.
   - **Implementation**: Use a deterministic model to capture the main trend and a probabilistic model to capture the residuals.

### Training Techniques for Stochastic Models

1. **Monte Carlo Dropout**
   - **Description**: Use dropout during both training and inference to approximate Bayesian inference in neural networks.
   - **Implementation**: Apply dropout to the neural network layers and perform multiple forward passes to obtain a distribution of predictions.

2. **Ensemble of Neural Networks**
   - **Description**: Train multiple neural networks with different initializations and/or subsets of the data to capture model uncertainty.
   - **Implementation**: Aggregate the predictions from multiple networks to obtain a probabilistic forecast.

3. **Variational Inference**
   - **Description**: Approximate the posterior distribution of the model parameters using variational methods.
   - **Implementation**: Use techniques like Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) to learn a distribution over the latent space.

By using these models and techniques, you can explicitly capture the stochastic nature of time series, providing more robust and reliable forecasts that account for uncertainty and variability in the data.

title: üîí Secure token transfer

messages.content: How do you securely pass an access token from an app (client) to an API service?

Passing an access token securely from an app (client) to an API service involves several best practices to ensure the token is not intercepted or misused. Here are the key steps:

1. **Use HTTPS**: Always use HTTPS to encrypt the data transmitted between the client and the server. This prevents man-in-the-middle attacks where an attacker could intercept the token.

2. **Authorization Header**: Pass the access token in the HTTP Authorization header. This is a standard practice and helps keep the token out of URLs, which can be logged or cached inappropriately.
   ```http
   GET /resource HTTP/1.1
   Host: api.example.com
   Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
   ```

3. **Token Expiry**: Ensure that the access tokens have a short expiry time. This limits the window of opportunity for an attacker to use a stolen token.

4. **Refresh Tokens**: Use refresh tokens to obtain new access tokens without requiring the user to re-authenticate. Refresh tokens should also be securely stored and transmitted.

5. **Secure Storage**: Store tokens securely on the client side. For web applications, use secure, HTTP-only cookies or secure storage mechanisms like the browser's `localStorage` or `sessionStorage` with appropriate security measures.

6. **CORS**: Configure Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) properly on the server to ensure that only trusted domains can access the API.

7. **Content Security Policy (CSP)**: Implement CSP to prevent cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks that could steal tokens from the client.

8. **Token Scopes**: Use scopes to limit the access granted by the token to only what is necessary for the operation being performed.

9. **Token Revocation**: Implement a mechanism to revoke tokens if they are suspected to be compromised.

10. **Logging and Monitoring**: Monitor and log access token usage to detect any unusual or unauthorized access patterns.

By following these best practices, you can significantly enhance the security of access token transmission between your app and API service.

I generate this access token from the app upon login. How do I securely store the token? I will be clicking around the app and such, going to various places, before I might need to send the access token to the API.

Securely storing access tokens on the client side is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and misuse. The method of storage can vary depending on the type of application (web, mobile, desktop). Here are some best practices for securely storing access tokens:

### For Web Applications

1. **HTTP-Only Cookies**:
   - Store the access token in an HTTP-only cookie. This prevents JavaScript from accessing the token, mitigating the risk of XSS attacks.
   - Ensure the cookie is marked as `Secure` to ensure it is only sent over HTTPS.
   - Example:
     ```javascript
     document.cookie = "access_token=<access_token>; Secure; HttpOnly; SameSite=Strict";
     ```

2. **Web Storage (localStorage or sessionStorage)**:
   - If you choose to use `localStorage` or `sessionStorage`, be aware that these are accessible via JavaScript and are vulnerable to XSS attacks.
   - Use Content Security Policy (CSP) to mitigate XSS risks.
   - Example:
     ```javascript
     localStorage.setItem('access_token', '<access_token>');
     ```

3. **In-Memory Storage**:
   - Store the token in memory (e.g., a JavaScript variable). This is the most secure method against XSS but the token will be lost on page refresh.
   - Example:
     ```javascript
     let accessToken = '<access_token>';
     ```

### For Mobile Applications

1. **Secure Storage**:
   - Use secure storage mechanisms provided by the platform, such as Keychain for iOS or Keystore for Android.
   - Example for iOS (Swift):
     ```swift
     let keychain = Keychain(service: "com.example.app")
     keychain["access_token"] = "<access_token>"
     ```
   - Example for Android (Java):
     ```java
     KeyStore keyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("AndroidKeyStore");
     keyStore.load(null);
     KeyStore.SecretKeyEntry secretKeyEntry = new KeyStore.SecretKeyEntry(secretKey);
     keyStore.setEntry("access_token", secretKeyEntry, null);
     ```

2. **Encrypted Storage**:
   - Use libraries that provide encrypted storage, such as EncryptedSharedPreferences for Android or libraries like `react-native-keychain` for React Native apps.

### For Desktop Applications

1. **Secure Storage**:
   - Use secure storage mechanisms provided by the operating system, such as the Windows Credential Locker or macOS Keychain.
   - Example for Windows (C#):
     ```csharp
     var vault = new Windows.Security.Credentials.PasswordVault();
     vault.Add(new Windows.Security.Credentials.PasswordCredential("app", "access_token", "<access_token>"));
     ```

2. **Encrypted Storage**:
   - Use libraries that provide encrypted storage for desktop applications, such as `electron-store` with encryption for Electron apps.

### General Best Practices

- **Token Expiry**: Ensure tokens have a short lifespan and use refresh tokens to obtain new access tokens.
- **Secure Transmission**: Always transmit tokens over HTTPS.
- **CSP and XSS Mitigation**: Implement Content Security Policy (CSP) and other XSS mitigation techniques to protect against token theft.
- **Token Revocation**: Implement a mechanism to revoke tokens if they are suspected to be compromised.

By following these best practices, you can securely store access tokens and protect them from unauthorized access and misuse.

title: üîß Azure work item

messages.content: In an Azure DevOps Connector, what is a "work item"

In Azure DevOps, a "work item" is a fundamental unit of work that is used to track and manage tasks, bugs, user stories, features, and other types of work within a project. Work items are used to plan, track, and discuss work across the team. Each work item represents a specific piece of work and contains fields to capture details such as title, description, state, priority, and assigned user.

Work items can be linked to each other to show dependencies, hierarchies, or related work. They are highly customizable, allowing teams to define their own workflows, states, and fields to match their specific processes and needs.

Common types of work items in Azure DevOps include:

- **User Story**: Represents a feature or requirement from the user's perspective.
- **Task**: Represents a specific piece of work that needs to be completed.
- **Bug**: Represents a defect or issue that needs to be fixed.
- **Epic**: Represents a large body of work that can be broken down into smaller tasks or user stories.
- **Feature**: Represents a grouping of related user stories or tasks.

Work items are a key component of Azure DevOps' agile project management capabilities, enabling teams to plan, track, and collaborate on their work effectively.

title: üõ† Fix Zod code

messages.content:
I have a TS type called QueryConfig. Help me fix this zod code:

z
		.object({
			id: z.string().uuid().refine(isMessageId).optional(), // parent message id to append to for a normal message, or the message id for a retry/continue
			inputs: z.optional(
				z
					.string()
					.trim()
					.min(1)
					.transform((s) => s.replace(/\r\n/g, "\n"))
			),
			queryConfig: z.optional(QueryConfig)
			is_retry: z.optional(z.boolean()),
			is_continue: z.optional(z.boolean()),
			web_search: z.optional(z.boolean()),
			files: z.optional(z.array(z.string())),
		})
		.parse(json);

To fix the Zod code, you need to ensure that `QueryConfig` is properly defined and imported. Assuming `QueryConfig` is a Zod schema, you should import it and use it directly in your schema definition. Here is the corrected code:

```typescript
import { z } from 'zod';
import { QueryConfig } from './path-to-query-config'; // Adjust the import path as necessary

const schema = z
  .object({
    id: z.string().uuid().refine(isMessageId).optional(), // parent message id to append to for a normal message, or the message id for a retry/continue
    inputs: z
      .string()
      .trim()
      .min(1)
      .transform((s) => s.replace(/\r\n/g, "\n"))
      .optional(),
    queryConfig: QueryConfig.optional(),
    is_retry: z.boolean().optional(),
    is_continue: z.boolean().optional(),
    web_search: z.boolean().optional(),
    files: z.array(z.string()).optional(),
  })
  .parse(json);
```

### Key Changes:
1. **Import `QueryConfig`**: Ensure that `QueryConfig` is imported from the correct path.
2. **Use `.optional()` on `QueryConfig`**: Use `QueryConfig.optional()` to make it optional.
3. **Reorder `.optional()` and other methods**: Ensure `.optional()` is called after other methods like `.trim()`, `.min()`, and `.transform()`.

This should fix the issues with your Zod schema.

title: üîÑ PDF to HTML

messages.content: how to convert pdf to html

To convert a PDF to HTML, you can use various tools and methods. Here are a few options:

### Online Tools
1. **Adobe Acrobat Online**: Adobe offers an online service to convert PDFs to HTML.
2. **Smallpdf**: Another online tool that provides PDF to HTML conversion.
3. **PDF2HTML**: A dedicated online converter for PDF to HTML.

### Software
1. **Adobe Acrobat Pro**: This software allows you to convert PDFs to various formats, including HTML.
2. **PDFMate PDF Converter**: A desktop application that supports PDF to HTML conversion.

### Command Line Tools
1. **pdftohtml**: A command-line utility that converts PDF files to HTML. It is part of the Poppler library.

### Programming Libraries
1. **Python**: Libraries like `pdfminer.six` and `PyMuPDF` can be used to extract text and images from PDFs and then generate HTML.
2. **Node.js**: Libraries like `pdf2html` can be used for conversion.

### Example Using `pdftohtml` Command Line Tool
1. **Install Poppler**: You need to install the Poppler utilities.
   - On Ubuntu: `sudo apt-get install poppler-utils`
   - On macOS: `brew install poppler`
2. **Convert PDF to HTML**: Use the `pdftohtml` command.
   ```sh
   pdftohtml input.pdf output.html
   ```

### Example Using Python
1. **Install pdfminer.six**:
   ```sh
   pip install pdfminer.six
   ```
2. **Convert PDF to HTML**:
   ```python
   from pdfminer.high_level import extract_text_to_fp
   from io import StringIO

   output_string = StringIO()
   with open('input.pdf', 'rb') as f:
       extract_text_to_fp(f, output_string, output_type='html')
   
   html_content = output_string.getvalue()
   with open('output.html', 'w') as f:
       f.write(html_content)
   ```

Choose the method that best fits your needs and technical comfort level.
how to convert pdf to html in python

To convert a PDF to HTML in Python, you can use libraries like `pdfminer.six` or `PyMuPDF`. Below are examples of how to use each of these libraries for the conversion.

### Using `pdfminer.six`

1. **Install `pdfminer.six`**:
   ```sh
   pip install pdfminer.six
   ```

2. **Convert PDF to HTML**:
   ```python
   from pdfminer.high_level import extract_text_to_fp
   from io import StringIO

   def convert_pdf_to_html(input_pdf_path, output_html_path):
       output_string = StringIO()
       with open(input_pdf_path, 'rb') as f:
           extract_text_to_fp(f, output_string, output_type='html')
       
       html_content = output_string.getvalue()
       with open(output_html_path, 'w') as f:
           f.write(html_content)

   # Example usage
   convert_pdf_to_html('input.pdf', 'output.html')
   ```

### Using `PyMuPDF` (also known as `fitz`)

1. **Install `PyMuPDF`**:
   ```sh
   pip install pymupdf
   ```

2. **Convert PDF to HTML**:
   ```python
   import fitz  # PyMuPDF

   def convert_pdf_to_html(input_pdf_path, output_html_path):
       doc = fitz.open(input_pdf_path)
       html_content = ""
       for page_num in range(len(doc)):
           page = doc.load_page(page_num)
           html_content += page.get_text("html")
       
       with open(output_html_path, 'w') as f:
           f.write(html_content)

   # Example usage
   convert_pdf_to_html('input.pdf', 'output.html')
   ```

### Explanation

- **pdfminer.six**: This library is focused on extracting text and information from PDF documents. The `extract_text_to_fp` function is used to convert the PDF content to HTML format.
- **PyMuPDF**: This library provides more comprehensive PDF handling capabilities, including text extraction and rendering. The `get_text("html")` method is used to extract the HTML content of each page.

Choose the library that best fits your needs. If you need more control over the PDF content and layout, `PyMuPDF` might be the better choice. If you are primarily focused on text extraction, `pdfminer.six` is a good option.
how to pass html files in unstructured io

To pass HTML files in Unstructured IO, you typically need to read the HTML content from the file and then process it according to the requirements of the Unstructured IO library or framework you are using. Below is a general approach to reading HTML files and passing their content for further processing.

### Example Using Python

1. **Read HTML File**: First, read the HTML content from the file.
2. **Process HTML Content**: Pass the HTML content to the Unstructured IO library or framework.

Here is a step-by-step example:

1. **Read HTML File**:
   ```python
   def read_html_file(file_path):
       with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
           html_content = file.read()
       return html_content

   # Example usage
   html_content = read_html_file('example.html')
   ```

2. **Process HTML Content**: Assuming you have a function or method in your Unstructured IO library that processes HTML content, you can pass the read content to it.

   ```python
   def process_html_content(html_content):
       # This is a placeholder for the actual processing logic
       # Replace this with the actual function/method from your Unstructured IO library
       processed_data = unstructured_io_library.process(html_content)
       return processed_data

   # Example usage
   processed_data = process_html_content(html_content)
   ```

### Full Example

Combining the steps above into a full example:

```python
def read_html_file(file_path):
    with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
        html_content = file.read()
    return html_content

def process_html_content(html_content):
    # This is a placeholder for the actual processing logic
    # Replace this with the actual function/method from your Unstructured IO library
    processed_data = unstructured_io_library.process(html_content)
    return processed_data

# Example usage
html_content = read_html_file('example.html')
processed_data = process_html_content(html_content)
```

### Notes

- **Encoding**: Ensure you use the correct encoding (e.g., `utf-8`) when reading the HTML file.
- **Unstructured IO Library**: Replace the placeholder `unstructured_io_library.process` with the actual function or method from the Unstructured IO library you are using.
- **Error Handling**: Add appropriate error handling to manage file reading and processing errors.

This approach allows you to read HTML files and pass their content to any Unstructured IO library or framework for further processing.
how to extract the tables from htlml file by using ustructured.io in python

To extract tables from an HTML file using the `unstructured.io` library in Python, you can follow these steps:

1. **Install Required Libraries**: Ensure you have the necessary libraries installed. You might need `unstructured`, `beautifulsoup4`, and `pandas` for handling HTML and extracting tables.

   ```sh
   pip install unstructured beautifulsoup4 pandas
   ```

2. **Read HTML File**: Read the HTML content from the file.

3. **Extract Tables**: Use `unstructured.io` along with `BeautifulSoup` to parse the HTML and extract tables.

Here is a step-by-step example:

### Step 1: Install Required Libraries
Make sure you have the required libraries installed:
```sh
pip install unstructured beautifulsoup4 pandas
```

### Step 2: Read HTML File
Read the HTML content from the file:
```python
def read_html_file(file_path):
    with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
        html_content = file.read()
    return html_content
```

### Step 3: Extract Tables
Use `BeautifulSoup` to parse the HTML and extract tables. You can then use `pandas` to convert the tables into DataFrame objects for easier manipulation.

```python
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd

def extract_tables_from_html(html_content):
    soup = BeautifulSoup(html_content, 'html.parser')
    tables = soup.find_all('table')
    
    extracted_tables = []
    for table in tables:
        df = pd.read_html(str(table))[0]
        extracted_tables.append(df)
    
    return extracted_tables

# Example usage
html_content = read_html_file('example.html')
tables = extract_tables_from_html(html_content)

# Print extracted tables
for i, table in enumerate(tables):
    print(f"Table {i+1}:")
    print(table)
    print()
```

### Full Example
Combining the steps into a full example:

```python
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd

def read_html_file(file_path):
    with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
        html_content = file.read()
    return html_content

def extract_tables_from_html(html_content):
    soup = BeautifulSoup(html_content, 'html.parser')
    tables = soup.find_all('table')
    
    extracted_tables = []
    for table in tables:
        df = pd.read_html(str(table))[0]
        extracted_tables.append(df)
    
    return extracted_tables

# Example usage
html_content = read_html_file('example.html')
tables = extract_tables_from_html(html_content)

# Print extracted tables
for i, table in enumerate(tables):
    print(f"Table {i+1}:")
    print(table)
    print()
```

### Notes
- **BeautifulSoup**: This library is used to parse the HTML content and find all `<table>` elements.
- **pandas**: The `pd.read_html` function is used to convert the HTML table into a DataFrame.
- **Error Handling**: Add appropriate error handling to manage file reading and parsing errors.

This approach allows you to extract tables from an HTML file and convert them into a format that is easy to manipulate and analyze using `pandas`.

title: üìã Standard workflow pattern

messages.content:
Is this a standard pattern?

"I created a PR to merge changes from feature branch to DEV. can you review and approve. once that is done, we can deploy on dev env using the DEV branch and then make a PR to QA branch in order to deploy to QA"

Yes, the pattern you described is a common workflow in software development, particularly in environments that use Git for version control and follow a branching strategy. Here's a breakdown of the steps:

1. **Create a PR (Pull Request) to merge changes from the feature branch to the DEV branch**: This is a standard practice to ensure that changes made in a feature branch are reviewed before being integrated into the development branch.

2. **Review and approve the PR**: Code review is an essential step to maintain code quality and catch potential issues early.

3. **Deploy on the DEV environment using the DEV branch**: Once the PR is approved and merged, the changes are deployed to the development environment for further testing.

4. **Make a PR to the QA branch to deploy to QA**: After successful testing in the development environment, a new PR is created to merge changes from the DEV branch to the QA branch. This allows the changes to be deployed to the QA environment for more rigorous testing.

This workflow helps in maintaining a structured and controlled process for code integration and deployment across different environments.
I thought branching structure should be orthogonal to deployment structure.

You are correct that, ideally, the branching structure should be orthogonal to the deployment structure. This means that the way you manage your branches in version control should not be tightly coupled with how you deploy your code to different environments. However, in practice, many teams find it convenient to align their branching strategy with their deployment pipeline for simplicity and clarity.

Here are some key points to consider:

1. **Branching Strategy**:
   - **Feature Branches**: Used for developing new features or bug fixes. These branches are typically short-lived and merged back into a main branch (e.g., `develop` or `main`) once the work is complete.
   - **Develop Branch**: Often used as an integration branch for feature branches. It serves as a staging area for changes that are ready for testing.
   - **Release Branches**: Created from the `develop` branch when preparing for a new release. This branch is used for final testing and bug fixing before the release.
   - **Main/Master Branch**: Represents the production-ready code. Only thoroughly tested and stable code is merged into this branch.

2. **Deployment Strategy**:
   - **Continuous Integration (CI)**: Automatically builds and tests code changes in feature branches and the `develop` branch.
   - **Continuous Deployment (CD)**: Automatically deploys code changes to different environments (e.g., DEV, QA, Staging, Production) based on certain triggers or approvals.

3. **Orthogonal Approach**:
   - **Feature Toggles**: Use feature toggles to control the release of new features independently of the branching structure. This allows you to deploy code to production without necessarily enabling the new feature for all users.
   - **Environment Configuration**: Use environment-specific configurations to manage deployments. This way, the same codebase can be deployed to different environments with different settings.

4. **Practical Alignment**:
   - While the ideal scenario is to keep branching and deployment structures orthogonal, aligning them can simplify the workflow. For example, using a `develop` branch for the DEV environment and a `release` branch for the QA environment can make it easier to track which code is deployed where.

In summary, while the branching structure should ideally be orthogonal to the deployment structure, aligning them can provide practical benefits and simplify the workflow. The key is to find a balance that works best for your team's needs and ensures a smooth and efficient development and deployment process.

title: üß™ Lam's wafer slot mapping

messages.content: What is the Lam response to wafer slot mapping?

### Answer: Comply

### Explanation:
Lam Research complies with the wafer slot mapping requirements. The compliance includes both actions of associating the wafer to the slot within the carrier and associating the wafer ID to the slot within the carrier, as well as generating the slot map results as defined in SEMI E87 [3].

Lam SMEs question#1: Robot/wafer Precision (um): what does 1 um in your example mean? Please provide more details of your customer‚Äôs definition of robot/wafer precision.
Intel AT answers: For the robot precision in micron, it is simply the robot‚Äôs accuracy/ repeatability for wafer placement. The example of 1 um would represent a plus or minus delta in wafer placement that we would consider in spec for a normally functioning robot. The customer just wants to see this unit delta in microns. Lam SMEs question#2: Position Name
(Coordinates)¬†You use a ‚Äòred dot‚Äô in your example. Is your customer expecting us to enter some free text such as ‚ÄòContact point‚Äô?
Intel AT answers: For the contact point naming, the Deposition and Platform groups have provided relatively genetic names of points in the various released documents over the years. I have attached the recently created Striker Carbide contact point document (202-A71196-002_A) as an example of this. It has a legend on page one identifying the contact points with simple shapes and names, the shapes can then be easily identified in the contact maps on the following pages. Lam SMEs question#3: For Dep tool that does not align to the notch, how does your customer handle that? What does your customer want Lam to use as zero degree?
Intel AT answers: For notch alignment, the customer stated that we should assume wafer notches are oriented to/facing the FOUP door, and that we can assume this is the zero degree point. Again on the attached example, the notch is called out on page 1 and the contact maps show its position as the zero degree mark on the flowing pages. Intel AT clarification to Lam SMEs questions

SUPPLER COMMENT: Wafer Tracking Requirement for Multi-module Equipment
For any multi module equipment, it is required for the equipment to report wafer processing and wafer location events to the host whenever the wafer is being processed through each module. Such events are also to be logged in the equipment log file for future references.
Such equipment wafer tracking capability has to be compliant with SEMI E90 standard.

It can avoid user is hard to identify and handle the job failed during multi-FOUP's job.
Allow host to exchange/sort wafer position, for instance Slot1, 2 changes to Slot2, 1. This function should be accomplished without empty carrier assistance.

EQP notify expired event automatically.

When there is measurement data error (e.g. empty value), tool has to allow host to execute re-measure job without removing carrier.
Production people , don't want to : CANCEL JOB-IN , REMOVE FOUP and then PLACE FOUP for re-measure.

Tool must provide the alarm or event report while the dummy wafer usage count expired.
EQP notify expired event automatically.
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: _______NA__________________________________________
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________ Automation Acceptance
LEVEL TWO (Automation Performance Level) EAP developer has finished EAP development and is ready to release the equipment to volume production environment. HiDM shall focus on the reliability and stability of the automation functions at this level. The following items will be the monitoring criteria.
(a) Requirement of data quality mentioned in chapter 3 and chapter 4 shall be monitored and validated.
(b) HiDM is executing an EAP release cycle, this cycle goes through the authorized persons from different departments. The equipment automation is accepted when the release cycle is finished.
(c) If any of item (a) is violated, it is tool vendor‚Äôs obligation to send either software head or programmer to HiDM FAB to diagnose and resolve the problems. The aggressive attitude is encouraged.
(d) If the problem is not resolved when the monitoring period comes to end, the monitor period shall be extended until the problem is resolved.Worse, the equipment shall be rejected.
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: ________Complied___________________________________
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________ Operation Scenario
Sections 2.26.1 to 3.26.4 state the minimum requirement for HiDM material processing scenario. Notes: Definition of ‚ÄúSlot Mapping‚Äù in sections 2.26.1 to 2.26.4:
(1) If wafer ID reading device is present, i. ‚ÄúSlot Mapping‚Äù will include both actions of associating wafer to slot within carrier AND associating wafer ID to slot within carrier
ii. ‚ÄúSlot Map‚Äù will be results of ‚ÄúSlotMap‚Äù and ‚ÄúContentMap‚Äù as defined in SEMI E87
(2) If wafer ID reading device is NOT present
i. ‚ÄúSlot Mapping‚Äù will be the action of associating wafer to slot within carrier
ii. ‚ÄúSlot Map‚Äù will be results of ‚ÄúSlotMap‚Äù as defined in SEMI E87

Do not comply.

SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: ____________________________________________________
SUPPLER COMMENT: ____________________________________________________________ Detail Requirement Descriptions
Equipment User Interface
Wafer ID and CARRIER ID Display User Interface (UI)
For equipment that are equipped with Carrier ID Read/Write (CIDRW) system and Wafer ID reading system, the CARRIER ID and the Wafer ID have to be visible to the operator through the equipment user interface
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: _ Comply _
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________ Equipment Terminal Service
This function allows the host to display information on the equipment display device or the operator of the equipment to send information to the host. All equipment is to support this basic terminal service requirement.
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: _ Comply _
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________ There must be no UI display unit installed within the ‚Äúrestricted zone‚Äù
There must be no UI display unit installed within the ‚Äúrestricted zone‚Äù. ‚ÄúRestricted zone‚Äù is defined to be any area that is directly above the equipment Load Port or in-between the Load Port if that distance is less than 16 cm
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: _ Comply _
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________
Equipment Host Communications Capabilities
Equipment Control Mode
¬∑ Equipment has to provide the following three standard communication mode with host: Offline, Online/Local and Online/Remote. Definition of these modes is as defined in the SEMI E30 (GEM) standard.
¬∑ For every mode change that is generated at the equipment, equipment must send an event to the host to notify the mode change following SEMI E30 (GEM) standard.
¬∑ Equipment must allow host to query and change the communication mode.
¬∑ Equipment must provide separate equipment control mode for each Load Port and the control mode for each Load Port must be exclusively independent on the other Load Ports in the equipment
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: _ Comply _
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________ Equipment Single Communication Interface
Equipment has to provide a single physical communication link between the host and the equipment to perform remote commands and monitor events for the following distinct automation parts:
¬∑ Wafer location tracking, movement control and processing within Equipment and within equipment multi-modules (if there is any)
¬∑ Wafer movement control and tracking at Load Port
¬∑ Carrier ID read and write
¬∑ Equipment Signal Tower Control
¬∑ Wafer ID read (If equipment is equipped with wafer ID reading system)
The communication protocol must be compliant to SEMI E37 and E54 SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: M/D
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________
Equipment SEMI E37 [HSMS] Basic Requirement
¬∑ Equipment physical link has to be at least, maybe in more high rate 10/100 Ethernet connections with RJ45 connector
¬∑ Need to be able to handle all normal communications and control functions at sub-second response time
¬∑ Able to process no less than 200 trace data points per second while not impacting the equipment normal processing
¬∑ Need to support SEMI E37.1 [HSMS-SS]
¬∑ Any active communications with host should not have significant impact on the other TCP/IP or HSMS entities on the network Communication Standards Requirement
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: M/D
SUPPLER COMMENT: __________________________________________________________ Equipment SEMI E30 [GEM] Requirement

(1) State Models
(2) Equipment Processing States
(3) Host-initiated S1F13/S1F14 Scenario
(4) Event Notification
(5) On-Line Identification
(6) Error Messages
(7) Documentation
(8) Control (Operator initiated)
(9) Establish communications
(10) Dynamic Event Report configuration
(11) Variable Data Collection
(12) Status Data Collection
(13) Trace Data Collection
(14) Alarm Management
(15) Remote Control
(16) Equipment Constants
(17) Process Program Management
(18) Material Movement (according to SEMI E87)
(19) Equipment Terminal Service
(20) Clock
(21) Limits Monitoring
(22) Spooling
(23) Control (Host-initiated)
¬∑ Suppliers are required to document the operational behavior of their equipment using state model methodology [E30]
SUPPLIER COMPLIANCE LEVEL: M/D

List of Variables

Supplementary requirements
Sorter supplementary requirement
1. Sorter Equipment equipped with n load ports must support split/merge process among n FOUPs in one Control Job.---
2. Sorter Equipment must support to align angle by wafer base. ---
3. When carrier with one control job gets COMPLETED, equipment must support to create another control job for same carrier without removal. ---
Furnace tools supplementary requirement---
1) Furnace tool must include the monitor wafer control, layout control, filled dummy and side dummy control.
2) Furnace tool must provide OBJECT ID for process/recipe step change event.
3) Furnace tool must provide the capability to allow host to tune process parameters for each batch.
4) Slot map must be verified in loadport.
5) Furnace tool must report boat/tube information by wafer when batch end. The information includes:
¬∑ LotID, WaferID and SlotId
¬∑ Wafer position in boat/tube
6) Tool should support Host send the multiple ‚ÄúCarrier-Out‚Äù commands simultaneously, and equipment must be capable of queuing these ‚ÄúCarrier-Out‚Äù commands and execute them sequentially.
7) Tool should can Support Host ‚ÄúCarrier Out‚Äù command both with and without portId specification.
Wet Bench tools supplementary requirement---
1) Equipment must support to query :
¬∑ Current life count and lifetime
¬∑ Life count and lifetime for chemical change
2) tool must report information by wafer when batch end:
¬∑ Lot ID, Wafer ID, and Slot ID
¬∑ tank ID and wafer position
3) Tool should support Host send the multiple ‚ÄúCarrier-Out‚Äù commands simultaneously, and equipment must be capable of queuing these ‚ÄúCarrier-Out‚Äù commands and execute them sequentially. 4) Tool should can Support Host ‚ÄúCarrier Out‚Äù command both with and without portId specification.
General supplementary requirement for all tools---
1) Tool should report processed wafer count for each PJ.
2) In both automatic and manual handoffs, host must make no difference in communication between the AUTO handoff and the MANUAL handoff. Must notify host when handoff state changes.
3) Equipment suppliers should provide detailed Recipe Format Document to decode recipe body.
4) Before Recipe body/list upload, host should not set any equipment constants in equipment to identify what kind of recipe needs to upload. 5) Recipe parameter tuning in S16Fy must be limited within current PJ.

4) Equipment suppliers‚Äô Services After Automation Software Acceptance:

title: ü§ñ Etch response to MTTR

messages.content: What is the Etch response to ATM Robot MTTR less than 2 hours?

### Answer:
Do not comply.

### Explanation:
The response to the specification that the Mean Time to Repair (MTTR) for a Track type ATM robot should be ‚â§2 hours is "Do not comply." The reason provided is that robot replacement and teaching take much longer, and the exact duration depends on the specific robot issue [4].

VTM Vortex Robot Health Check (SW2300)
Reference Doc 839-293507-003_A Target Product & FID	NSR Title	Problem statement	NSR Description & Requirement	Requestor All Etch /Depo. products with VTM Vortex robot on SW 2300 including FID 223089	N514148-FB SW SHW 23 AUTO RBOT CH	There is no function robot condition check during motion.
There are cases where robots fail during running the production and replace them, So it can cause wafer broken or particles issue happened.
In case of the Nexus SW version, Auto Health check function has been developed.	Reference NSR is N509695-FB SW AUTO RBOT CHCK. "Vortex robot support for Auto Health Check (AHC) function‚Äú This NSR is for S/W 2300. S/W license is only needed.	Samsung Customer
‚Äπ#‚Ä∫
LAM RESEARCH Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
‚Äπ#‚Ä∫
CONFIDENTIAL
LAM RESEARCH
Lam ‚ÄòComply with NSR‚Äô response VTM Vortex Robot Health Check (SW2300) Scope of the NSR: * For every robot movement, the tool will report the max & min of every individual motor position error & motor torque
SVID will be assigned
Preliminary resources estimate (e.g. engineering hours to develop capability such as firmware & software)
Mechatronics (40 man-hours per robot type; 4 robot types total ÔÉ† 160 man-hours total)
Software (same as Mechatronics ÔÉ† 160 man-hours total)
*In scope Dep tools: Mach 1, Mach 4, Mach IQ
* In scope Etch tools: Sense.i ‚Äπ#‚Ä∫
LAM RESEARCH Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
Microsoft_PowerPoint_Presentation.pptx
Vacuum Robot AHC Phase II
Overview
Mechatronics
06/17/15
4x3W-v1 Lam Research Corp. | Confidential
‚Äπ#‚Ä∫
1
7/27/2022
Auto Health Check (AHC) is designed to measure the relative "health" condition of the robot
AHC routine measures key robot parameters during motion to determine if robot is still within expected operating condition
AHC does not represent metric of wafer placement accuracy within the chamber which is still controlled by the robot firmware placement accuracy window settings independent of AHC
Robots built to the same quality standard do expect to show some variation in measured motor parameters (position error, torque) during robot operation as a function of variation in operating conditions and part tolerances
What AHC should be used for
Determining relative health condition of the robot and detect potential sign of early failure. Lam has identified several key signatures indicative of ferrofluidic seal bearing failure that can be used as guideline
What AHC should not be used for
Determining metric of robot wafer placement accuracy to chamber ultimately measured by the on-wafer performance (process uniformity)
Setting expectation that all robots need to operate under a tight tolerance of health-related parameter spec
Driving tighter repeatability of robot measurable health check metrics by sequential tightening of SPC specs
Auto Health Check (AHC) Overview
4x3W-v1 Lam Research Corp. | Confidential
‚Äπ#‚Ä∫
2
7/27/2022
AHC SPC Limits
AHC SPC limits are established to allow some variations in the robot operating condition
These SPC limits should not be treated the same as process-related SPC where tight tolerance is expected as they are not a direct correlation to wafer quality results
AHC Recommended Implementation
AHC is recommended to be paired with Manual Health Check (MHC) process and not be used as sole determining factor in judging robot‚Äôs health or replacement
AHC is intended to automated high-level measurement of robot health. Robot that triggers AHC excursion should be evaluated with the MHC process to determine if the excursion is sign of problem or to be monitored

### Answer:
Do not comply.

### Explanation:
The response to the requirement that the MTTR (Mean Time to Repair) of a Track type ATM robot should be ‚â§2 hours is "Do not comply." The reason provided is that robot replacement and teaching take much longer, and it depends on the exact robot issue [4].

title: üß™ Lam's wafer slot mapping

messages.content: What is the Lam response to wafer slot mapping?

### Answer: Comply

### Explanation:
Lam Research complies with the wafer slot mapping requirements. The compliance includes both actions of associating the wafer to the slot within the carrier and associating the wafer ID to the slot within the carrier, as well as generating the slot map results as defined in SEMI E87 [3].

content.page_content:
Intel Wafer Backside Touch Points Request
Lam response (For Dep & Etch tools, slide#5) 11/12/2021
Added response for Clean tools in slide#6 (12/9/2021) wide-16x9W-v2 ‚Äπ#‚Ä∫ Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
1
4/23/2024
Purpose of the customer request
Intel is wants to add their Striker Carbide systems (SPK) wafer backside contact information to an existing database. Customer Specific Request:
Provide wafer backside touch point information for SPK systems. This includes the full wafer path from FOUP to module and back (TM and PM). All data points should be grouped by placement location (e.g. ATM robot endeffector, Inbound LL, Ped 1, etc.)
Touch point: radius (in um)
The precise distance the touch point is from the center of the wafer in microns Theta ( in polar coordinates) Orientation of touch point in polar coordinates (Degrees from 0ÔÇ∞ to 360ÔÇ∞)
Assume out going wafer notch is facing the FOUP door and this is at 270 degrees
Touch point size (um2)
Approx. area of touch point (does not need to be very precise incase there are IP concerns) Intel Wafer Backside Touch Points Request
SPK (Striker Carbide) Touch Point Info Request for now but scope will include Dep, Etch, Clean products CEID	Outgoing Notch Orientation	Robot/wafer Precision (um)	Position Name
(Coordinates)	Touch point radius (um)	Touch point theta	Touch point size (um2) Striker Carbid (SPK) wide-16x9W-v2 ‚Äπ#‚Ä∫ Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
Intel‚Äôs request is to fill out the example table below
Radius of touch point measured from center of the wafer out
Theta of touch point in polar coordinates 0ÔÇ∞ to 360ÔÇ∞
Touch point approx. size in um2 (does not need to be precise)
Example Table CEID	Outgoing Notch Orientation	Robot/wafer Precision (um)	Position Name
(Coordinates)	Touch point radius (um)	Touch point theta	Touch point approx. size (um2) Tool name	270	1	Red dot 84,000	50ÔÇ∞	1000 Radian measurement Polar coordinates wide-16x9W-v2 ‚Äπ#‚Ä∫ Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
Lam SMEs question#1: Robot/wafer Precision (um): what does 1 um in your example mean? Please provide more details of your customer‚Äôs definition of robot/wafer precision.
Intel AT answers: For the robot precision in micron, it is simply the robot‚Äôs accuracy/ repeatability for wafer placement. The example of 1 um would represent a plus or minus delta in wafer placement that we would consider in spec for a normally functioning robot. The customer just wants to see this unit delta in microns. Lam SMEs question#2: Position Name
(Coordinates)¬†You use a ‚Äòred dot‚Äô in your example. Is your customer expecting us to enter some free text such as ‚ÄòContact point‚Äô?
Intel AT answers: For the contact point naming, the Deposition and Platform groups have provided relatively genetic names of points in the various released documents over the years. I have attached the recently created Striker Carbide contact point document (202-A71196-002_A) as an example of this. It has a legend on page one identifying the contact points with simple shapes and names, the shapes can then be easily identified in the contact maps on the following pages. Lam SMEs question#3: For Dep tool that does not align to the notch, how does your customer handle that? What does your customer want Lam to use as zero degree?
Intel AT answers: For notch alignment, the customer stated that we should assume wafer notches are oriented to/facing the FOUP door, and that we can assume this is the zero degree point. Again on the attached example, the notch is called out on page 1 and the contact maps show its position as the zero degree mark on the flowing pages. Intel AT clarification to Lam SMEs questions
wide-16x9W-v2 ‚Äπ#‚Ä∫ Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
Lam AT will populate the table format below using information provided by PG with an approved NSR. (wafer contact map drawing)
Touch point radius, Touch point theta, Touch point size, Position Name (Coordinate)
For Outgoing Notch Orientation, Lam response: Notch position to be defined in drawing, either at 6 o‚Äôclock or 12 o‚Äôclock
For Robot/Wafer Precision, Lam response: +/- 500 um
No MCA contact point for any pedestal (lift pin only)
Lam response (for Dep & Etch tools)
Comply with NSR CEID	Outgoing Notch Orientation	Robot/wafer Precision (um)	Position Name
(Coordinates)	Touch point radius (um)	Touch point theta	Touch point size (um2) Striker Carbid (SPK) wide-16x9W-v2 ‚Äπ#‚Ä∫ Confidential ‚Äì Limited Access and Use
Clean (EOS) products have edge-contact only handling and chucks. There are no backside touch points Note: Assuming Intel asked only about backside touch points, and not about wafer bevel touch points
Clean (EOS) products do not have notch alignment as not required for process performance The notch orientation will change up to 2¬∞ in either direction, unless wafer shift option is used
